creator: George.Lindholm@ubc.ca
text:
The -force option to catalina.sh is executed too fast.

The "stop" command can return even though the JVM is still running so killing the process immediately can
cause problems for the JVM, e.g. files marked as delete on exit are not removed.

Tomcat 6 has the same problem

Created attachment 20851
Slow down -force execution

Add a 10 (???) second delay between having issued the "stop" command
and issuing the kill comman. This gives the JVM time to finish
cleaning up.
creator: George.Lindholm@ubc.ca

markt@apache.org
text:
Could someone provide a use case for this. The whole point of -force is to kill
the process when a normal stop fails.

creator: George.Lindholm@ubc.ca
text:
The assumption is that the once the shutdown command has been issued
and the process has finished, that this means that the JVM is really
dead. In fact, the JVM may still be running for a short time after 
Tomcat has "gone" away. So the 'kill' command is executed too soon.
In my case, this means that any temporary files created with the
"delete on exit" flag are not removed, eventually filling up the
file system.

creator: markt@apache.org
text: So why can't you just not use the -force option and let Tomcat stop normally?

Because every once in a blue moon, the JVM does not exit, and it has to be killed
so that we restart the service. Better to have it done by the shutdown script
rather then being called at 4 in morning because the service can't be restarted.
creator: George.Lindholm@ubc.ca

text:
OK. I understand your use case now.

If the JVM doesn't stop cleanly then something is wrong that needs to be fixed.
I think adding this feature would encourage people to use -force all the time
which would mask that the stop was not clean which in turns hides the fact there
is some underlying issue.

I would be -1 on the patch as is since it removes some existing functionality
and the delay is not configurable. With the warning restored and the delay made
configurable I would be -0. Of course, I am only one person. The rest of the
community may have very different views.
